title: What are some examples of four character Chinese names? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am aware of the (albeit small) trend today of having the sole child of the two parents use the combined surnames of the parents, but those names are normally three character names, to give the appearance that the name is a single-character surname and a double-character given name. Mr Li who married Ms Chen might register the child’s name as Li Chen Mei, with Li registered as the surname. Most four-character Chinese names are formed out of very ancient surnames with two characters, like 慕容、欧阳、司马 or 司徒, together with a two-character given name. One of my game character in a Chinese MMO was given the name of 欧阳美女 (the given name being “pretty lass” in vernacular talk), just for laughs. Other four-character Chinese names are actually the transliterated forms of names of minority tribes like Uighurs or Manchu. In fact, the clan name (surname) of the last Chinese Emperor Puyi is a four-character name 爱新觉罗. Some thoughts for the question asker to think through!

Since we’re ignoring four character names with two character surnames, I presume the question is asking about potential three (or four) character surnames. The only two I can think of are the surnames of the emperors of the Qing and Yuan dynasties, 愛新覺羅 (Àixīnjuéluó, lit. “Golden”, originally the clan name of the Manchu rulers) and 孛兒只斤 (Bó'érzhījīn, Borjigin, the clan name of Genghis Khan and his decedents). But those are non-Han names. I’m also excluding things like Posthumous Names, which can be arbitrarily long - Cixi’s was 孝欽慈禧端佑康頤昭豫莊誠壽恭欽獻崇熙配天興聖顯皇后 (Xiào qīn cíxǐ duān yòu kāngyízhāo yù zhuāng chéngshòu gōng qīn xiàn chóng xī pèi tiān xìng shèng xiǎn huáng tàihòu). For a Chinese name to have four characters with a single-character surname, that would mean the given name would have to be three characters. Something like, I don’t know, 陳強紅國. I think that’s technically allowed these days, but I’ve never encountered it.
